I'm exhausted and need to go to bed. It's been a long day. But first, a thought. When I was younger (maybe 11, 12, 13) I remember that I would have some sort of an imposed bedtime, and of course, I was never actually tired yet. I had so much more energy then... and I would lie awake in bed for the longest time, sometimes more than an hour, daydreaming. First, I'll say that some of my daydreams put my actual dreams to shame. Let's not forget I'm talking about my middle school years here, which were, ahem, quite hormonal. (Just a bit.) While some of those thoughts still remain, urlLink at least in a much more mature sense , I realized tonight that I miss that energy. As much as laying down to sleep, and being so darn exhausted that I fall out soon after, may sound very appealing to those in the crowd, I miss those moments of thought. I very rarely get a chance to daydream during the day. If I try to close my eyes and imagine a different life, chances are, I'll crash my car and end up in the hospital, because when I'm driving is one of the few times of the day I (sometimes) have to myself. As I write this, I am remembering some of those daydreams. I think I'll try to go to bed early tomorrow and relive them. urlLink Don't dream it's over

Okay, now I've crossed over to the dark side. But it's all in the interest of knowlege. Last week, urlLink I talked about a book I was reading, Hackers: Heroes of the Computer Revolution , by Steven Levy. A history of the evolution of the personal computer, until about 1983. This week, I've started to read it's followup. Mr. Levy also wrote about the development of the Macintosh from 1983 to 2000, in Insanely Great . It's no big secret, and it's in the earlier post, but I'm not a big fan of the Macintosh, at least as a computer user. But I won't deny it's place in history. While it may not have gone down exactly as acted in the movie Pirates of Silicon Valley , yeah, Mr. Gates did steal the concept, at least in part, from the gullible fools at Apple, when he designed Windows. The irony, of course, is that when you read in Hackers about Mr. Gates, he started early on a crusade to stop people from pirating an early program he wrote (a BASIC interpreter) and even today uses copy protection on his products which is so annoying to the customers, modern hackers write cracks not only to get free software but to make software tolerable for legitimate users. That in itself isn't a new concept - annoying copy protection. Having to read urlLink vague symbols from a paper, as in Leisure Suit Larry 5, was one thing, but other games that did the same, adding red-tinted glasses to the mix, as in Maniac Mansion, made these games awful to play, even though the designers thought that they were "enhancing game play". Back on topic, however, even though I will never willingly own a Macintosh computer, I do respect some of the technological advancements it brought about, although I'm still of a mixed mind whether it was a good idea to make a computer for the idiots in the room (sorry, "Computer for the rest of us") as opposed to the power-users who used the more powerful PC's. Now that any Tom, Dick, and Harry can use a computer, there's more crap in the world, like the Hamster Dance web site. More later.

I'm currently re-reading a book that's been on my shelf for years, urlLink Hackers by Steven Levy. It's a history of the evolution of the personal computer from the mid-1950's through the days when the Apple ][ was in power; the edition of the book I own was written on such a machine, as noted by the author. In re-reading the book I previously read at age 16, I'm coming to new appreciation for the origins of the computer culture, and learning the etymology of words that are used every day now, such as the word munged (from "Mash Until No Good", used with telephone systems engeneering parts). I've lost a lot of the computer-science nerdiness that followed me through high school; and even today the average 16-year-old probably has a better idea of what the current fastest cprocessor is out there and how many small fries they'll have to sell at Mickey-d's in order to upgrade the lousy hunk-o-junk they currently own. But I'm still fascinated in the history. One of my regular blog readings is urlLink Dan Sandler , whom I have observed (read: stalked) since he established a web presence back in the early-to-mid 90's. To set the stage: I was the operator of the school's BBS system, and had access to the internet through a friend who developed an early version of an ISP. (Not many 15 year-olds had free internet access, let alone any idea what the internet was back then.) He's become my doorway to the other side -- after all, I grew up and programmed on the PC, the obvious choice for the analytical, straight-collar thinker. He's a Mac addict, which has long been the choice of the creative person. When I was 12 and older, the only satisfied Mac users I ever met were either musicians. graphic designers, or layout professionals. Everyone else at the time preferred the competition. Dan's blog regualrly links to urlLink Apple folklore sites, with easter egg tidbits of the development of the Mac and it's relatives. I've gained a newfound respect for a computer I refuse to own; I'll nevr have one, but I appreciate all the hard work and energy that went into it. What's the modern lingo? Oh, yes: don't hate the playaz, hate the game. Actually, I like the game, just not the end result.

After today, I've lost all respect for human nature. When leaving a department store today, I came upon a child in the parking lot who had become seperated from his mother. His name was Shana, and was no more than 4 years old. He was in the parking lot, crying that he wanted his mommy. After talking to him for a moment, I took him inside the store in order to help find his mother. I approached the cashier, and asked her to page security because I had found a lost child. She shrugged, and then went to complete a personal conversation she was having. I became insistant, and she finally complied. Security came, and we talked with the child and comforted him. Eventually, the mother was found, and this part was worst of all. The mother was less concerned about the child than we were. She didn't even ask the child if he was okay or what happened. I would have done the same thing again, no matter what, but it hurt me a little that only the head of security said "Thank you". The mother did not say this to myself or the security staff. That child deserves better than this woman as a mother. But I am grateful for the chance to help this child, if only for a short while.
